channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Open Source: Stung by Pope’s Remarks on Armenian Genocide, Turkish Minister Insults Argentina
item.description: The minister for European affairs suggested that Argentines as whole, and not just Pope Francis, had been brainwashed by rich and powerful Armenians in their midst.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: World Briefing: France: Surveillance Powers Urged
item.description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls called Monday for emergency government surveillance powers in case of an exceptional threat, a move prompted by the deadly Paris attacks in January.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Sierra Leone: Ebola Trial Begins
item.description: Researchers began vaccinating volunteers in Sierra Leone on Monday with an experimental Ebola vaccine.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Militants Have Displaced 800,000 Children, Unicef Reports
item.description: A new Unicef report says that about 800,000 children have been forced from their homes in northeast Nigeria by the Boko Haram uprising, with many separated from their families and some subjected to abuse and forced marriage.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Menace of Boko Haram
item.description: The coming change of government provides an opportunity for a new approach to security in Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: SALIL SHETTY

item.title: Memo From Panama: Talks With Cuba Earn U.S. Raves in Latin America
item.description: The question now is whether President Obama and his successors can capitalize on the new credibility Washington has earned, primarily through his rapprochement with Havana.
item.dc:creator: RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama’s talk with President Raúl Castro of Cuba drew praise from Latin American leaders and an editorial in El Universal with the headline “A New Era in the Americas.”

item.title: Senate Leaders and White House Make Their Cases on Iran Deal Legislation
item.description: Leaders of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee negotiated to possibly shorten a review period in legislation that would give Congress influence over President Obama’s nuclear accord with Iran.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN WEISMAN and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Eduardo Galeano, Uruguayan Voice of Anti-Capitalism, Is Dead at 74
item.description: Mr. Galean was a Uruguayan writer who blended literature, journalism and political satire in reflecting on the vagaries, injustices and small victories of history.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Eduardo Galeano, after a speech at the National Pedagogical University in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, in 2005.

item.title: Ex-Blackwater Guards Sentenced to Long Prison Terms in 2007 Killings of Iraqi Civilians
item.description: The men had been among several private American security guards who fired into Baghdad’s crowded Nisour Square in September 2007, and last October they were convicted of killing 14 unarmed Iraqis.
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Magana/AP; Cliff Owen/AP; Cliff Owen/AP; Douglas C. Pizac/AP
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Dustin L. Heard, Nicholas A. Slatten, Evan S. Liberty and Paul A. Slough.

item.title: New Report on Washington Post Writer Seen as Prelude to Espionage Trial
item.description: The Iranian news report was laden with innuendo and unattributed assertions about Jason Rezaian, a Washington Post correspondent jailed in Tehran since last year.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Witnesses to Indian Loggers’ Killing Dispute Police Claims of Self-Defense
item.description: Day laborers became casualties in a decades-old war over the red sandalwood, an endangered tree often targeted by smugglers.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Gazprom Warns Europe Over Price of Natural Gas
item.description: The head of the Russian energy giant said that if the E.U. angled for a single price for its natural gas, it would likely be at higher end of the current spectrum.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Havana Journal: American Flags Popping Up in Cuba on Everything but a Pole
item.description: Warming relations have brought a burst of popularity for Old Glory, which Cubans are displaying on apartments, cars and especially their clothing.
item.dc:creator: RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: The thaw in relations between the United States and Cuba has sprinkled images of Old Glory in the streets of the capital.

item.title: Questions and Answers About the Armenian Genocide
item.description: Pope Francis’ description of the killing of Armenians 100 years ago as a genocide has elevated historical arguments about what happened then.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: A Tactical Shift Sweeps Soccer, Only It Comes From the Police
item.description: Matches between clubs from different countries remain a potential source of violence, but peaceful strategies are replacing “batons and barking dogs” in some European cities.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Fans gathering near the Barcaccia, a fountain in downtown Rome, before a Europa League soccer match between Roma and Feyenoord in February, when Feyenoord fans battled with the police and were said to be responsible for damage to the fountain.

item.title: Putin Lifts Ban on Russian Missile Sales to Iran
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin moved swiftly to take advantage of a possible thaw in relations over a potential deal curbing Iran’s nuclear ambitions.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: An S-300 antiaircraft missile system on display in Russia. Russia’s sale of the missiles to Iran is worth an estimated $800 million and is further straining relations with Washington.

item.title: Jin Youzhi, Sibling of China’s Last Emperor, Dies at 96
item.description: Mr. Jin, the half brother of Henry Pu Yi, the last of the Manchu dynasty to rule China, lived a simple life as a primary school educator.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Drone Strikes in Yemen Said to Set a Dangerous Precedent
item.description: A study of American drone strikes in Yemen concludes that the Obama administration has not followed its own rules to avoid civilian casualties.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: A building in the Yemeni province of Shabwah that was destroyed by an American drone strike targeting Qaeda forces in 2013.

item.title: Voting Opens in Sudan, but Many Are Resigned to Bashir’s Re-election
item.description: The European Union has criticized the Sudanese government for holding elections during violent conflict and political unrest.
item.dc:creator: ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: A woman cast her ballot on Monday at a polling station in Izba, an impoverished neighborhood on the outskirts of Khartoum, Sudan.

item.title: Afghan Army Is Tested by the Taliban as Fighting Season Begins
item.description: At least 20 soldiers were killed in fierce fighting in Afghanistan’s remote northeast corner.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
